Award.AwardTitle: Workshop: The Relevance of Culture in Disaster Recovery (October 13-16, 2016, Colorado State University)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The overarching question addressed by the workshop supported by this award is: Are there certain kinds of cultural practices, values, and beliefs that, in locations at high-risk for natural disaster, are especially important to support in the face of the profound upheaval that natural disasters produce? Recent research into individual post-disaster situations has found that it is possible to reduce both immediate and long-term suffering by attending to the cultural strengths of impacted communities. Now Dr. Katherine E. Browne (Colorado State University) and Dr. Caela B. O'Connell (University of Tennessee) will convene researchers and practitioners experienced in the science and practice of disaster response to identify commonalities across different disaster contexts. Through this approach, the workshop aims to convert complex concepts of culture, community, and resilience into practical and actionable outcomes for researchers and practitioners working in disaster response and recovery. This approach also will further social science theory of community resilience and post-disaster recovery.

The workshop will take place over three days in Fort Collins, Colorado. Working with professional facilitators, participants will be explicitly focused on how to identify and mobilize cultural elements within communities to influence the rebuilding experience and improve disaster response. Workshop participants will create a template of cultural considerations that will later be tested across different field research sites in communities working to recover from disasters. The tested and refined template will eventually be shared with first responders through a new network of disaster researchers and recovery practitioners. This network will assess the results of the protocol once tested, disseminate information and outcomes from the workshop, and work to improve future rebuilding and recovery outcomes. Cultivating this whole frame view of recovery will provide social scientists the perspective needed to develop a more rigorous social science of disasters. Equally important, it will help researchers, government agencies, and community organizations develop models for response and intervention that complement and support the needs and strengths of communities for the long-term.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In 2017--one of the worst years on record for natural hazards-- hurricanes, earthquakes, tornadoes, floods, wildfires collided with human populations, producing disaster for whole groups of people at the same time. The increasing frequency of disaster, along with the increasing severity of many types of events, have given the work of disaster recovery a high profile and revealed a troubling flaw in the system: people on the ground working on recovery are not communicating with academic researchers who have relevant insights to offer. Nor have academics been good about delivering their insights in useful ways. Considering the growing numbers of people who are facing the impacts of disaster, there is an urgent need to improve the speed and sustainability of recovery. The single best hope for meeting this need is to bridge the academic/practitioner gap.

This NSF award enabled the PIs to host a workshop to bring together disaster professionals and academic anthropologists committed to exploring “The Relevance of Culture in Disaster Recovery.” The workshop convened 12 participants and 2 professional facilitators at Colorado State University in October 2016. The process of the 2.5 days of work allowed time for uncomfortable tensions to arise that commonly separate the worlds of practitioners from that of academics—their backgrounds, work priorities, professional languages, and timeframes. According to the literature on workshops, conflict known as the “groan zone” occurs when participants begin winnowing down viable options for forward movement. And while every groan zone risks paralyzing the process of a workshop, working through such conflict with effective facilitation can produce transformative results.    

Workshop participants did linger in the groan zone, but with the help of our content facilitator and our graphic recording facilitator, everyone came to acknowledge the value of mutual recognition, clear language, and compromise. The workshop ended with a full consensus about the desirability of establishing an ongoing network across the academic/practitioner divide in the interest of reducing suffering among impacted groups. The mission of the network is to change practice and policy by helping promote methods and concepts related to integrating local cultural knowledge into recovery practice.

The most important impact of the workshop, then, was to formalize and name the bridging network we had established. The group became the Culture and Disaster Action Network (CADAN). Each network member got a Colorado State University ID number and access to a shared Canvas platform where we could easily communicate ideas and circulate drafts of documents.

As CADAN, we have communicated regularly by conference calls, email threads, our shared platform, and most recently, a second, in-person meeting in DC. Since forming CADAN, our network has developed plans to achieve the following goals, many of which have already been realized

1. participate in conferences to promote our topical concern to broader groups in the disaster field including NGOs and INGOs. Three conference presentations have already occurred, each with different subgroups of CADAN:

a) the 2017 Society for Applied Anthropology paper presentation about the benefits our network experienced by transcending the groan zone;

b) the 2017 UN Global Platform for Disaster Risk Reduction presentation in Mexico where another group presented on the importance of integrating cultural considerations in executing disaster risk reduction plans;

c) the 2017 Natural Hazards Workshop in which five CADAN members presented a hands-on interactive hour-long session about how to locate and leverage cultural values and practices in the context of disaster (all completed presentations).

2. develop brochures and handouts for the conferences (all completed)

3. develop a comprehensive website and social media presence (both completed):

--website: http://cultureanddisaster.org/ and

--Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/cultureanddisaster/?ref=bookmarks

4. create a CADAN Advisory Board (partially completed)

5. develop a statement for the Congressional Subcommittee on Disaster (in development).

6. develop teaching materials that could be used for FEMA Higher Ed and for Emergency Management courses across the country (in development)

7. collaborate with NGOs, government bodies, and/or private organizations to help them develop methods and strategies to locate and leverage cultural knowledge (in development)

The future of CADAN, the outgrowth of the NSF-funded workshop, looks very bright. We are already fielding requests for support from community organizations and local governments about how we can help them approach recovery in a culturally informed, participatory manner.
